description: From Middle English monstre, borrowed from Old French monstre, mostre, moustre, from Latin mōnstrum.

entries.meaning: (informal) Very large; worthy of a monster.

examples: The children decided Grover was a cuddly monster.

entries.meaning: A cruel, heartless, or antisocial person, especially a criminal.
examples: Get away from those children, you meatheaded monster!

Deducting then these cases, we have a large proportion of imperfect foetuses, which belonged to twin conceptions, and in which, therefore, the circulation of the monster may have essentially depended on that of the sound child.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A badly behaved child, a brat.

examples: Have you seen those powerlifters on TV? They're monsters.

entries.meaning: (informal) A prodigy; someone very talented in a specific domain.
examples: That dude playing guitar is a monster.

entries.meaning: (gaming) A non-player character that player(s) fight against in role-playing games.

verbs.description: monster (third-person singular simple present monsters, present participle monstering, simple past and past participle monstered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make into a monster; to categorise as a monster; to demonise.
examples: Animals in our world have been monstered by human action as much as the free beasts of the pre-lapsarian state were monstered by the primal crime.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To behave as a monster to; to terrorise.
examples: In 2002, American interrogators on the ground in Afghanistan developed a technique they called “monstering.” The commander “instituted a new rule that a prisoner could be kept awake and in the booth for as long as an interrogator could last.” One “monstering” interrogator engaged in this for thirty hours.177

entries.meaning: (UK, live action role-playing games) To play (a series of) non-player characters as directed, without having the responsibility of organising the game itself; generally not limited to playing literal monsters or hostile combatants.
